name: 1-(3-methoxybenzoyl)-2-(1-naphthoyl)hydrazine
Reason: 1-(3-methoxybenzoyl)-2-(1-naphthoyl)hydrazine has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components: (1) The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The methoxy group (–OCH3) in place of a hydrogen atom increases the molecular weight and size, which generally raises the melting point. The benzene ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. (2) The naphthoyl group (1-naphthoyl) introduces a rigid structure with hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20°C. The methoxy group within the naphthoyl also introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10°C. The benzene ring within the naphthoyl introduces additional pi-pi interactions, estimated at around +10°C. The carbonyl group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, estimated at around +30°C. The total effect of these structural components can be estimated by adding their individual contributions.
